edge: Kahaani is a 2012 Indian Hindi-language thriller film co-written, co-produced, and directed by Sujoy Ghosh.
Vidya Balan plays the role of Vidya Bagchi in the film Kahaani.
The film Kahaani is set during the festival of Durga Puja in Kolkata.
In the film Kahaani, Vidya Balan plays the role of a pregnant woman looking for her missing husband in Kolkata during the festival of Durga Puja.
Parambrata Chatterjee plays the role of Assist Sub-Inspector Satyoki 'Rana' Sinha in the film Kahaani.
Nawazuddin Siddiqui plays the role of Inspector General A. Khan in the film Kahaani.
To avoid attracting attention, the crew of the film Kahaani often employed guerrilla-filmmaking techniques on Kolkata's city streets.
Made on a shoestring budget of ₹80 million (US$960,000), Kahaani is a notable film due to its creative portrayal of the city and use of local crew and cast members.

node_2: motherhood in a male-dominated indian society
edge: The film Kahaani explores themes of feminism and motherhood in a male-dominated Indian society.
The film Kahaani makes several allusions to Satyajit Ray's films, such as Charulata (1964), Aranyer Din Ratri (1970), and Joi Baba Felunath (1979).
The musical score and soundtrack of the film Kahaani are composed by Clinton Cerejo.
Cinematography for the film Kahaani is handled by Setu.
Editing for the film Kahaani is done by Namrata Rao.
Kahaani was released worldwide on 9 March 2012.
Critics praised the screenplay, the cinematography and the performances of the lead actors.
Two years later, Vidya Bagchi, a pregnant British-Indian software engineer, arrives in Kolkata from London during the Durga Puja festivities in search of her missing husband, Arnab Bagchi.
Assassin working undercover as a life insurance agent kills Agnes at the entrance of her house before she provides further help regarding former employee Milan Damji.
Suggests to Vidya that her husband resembles former employee Milan Damji, whose file is probably kept in the old NDC office.
Two Intelligence Bureau officials in Delhi—the chief Bhaskaran K. And his deputy Khan are attracted to the attempts to obtain Damji's records.
IB officials reveal that Damji was a rogue IB agent responsible for the poison gas attack.
Address on Damji's record leads Vidya and Rana to a dilapidated flat.
An errand boy from the neighbourhood tea stall identifies R. Sridhar, an NDC officer, as a frequent visitor to Damji's flat.
Vidya and Rana are mentioned together in the context.
Bob attempts, but fails, to kill Vidya and is soon run over by a truck during a chase.
Vidya and Rana break into Sridhar's office to verify his IP address,
Sridhar returns to his office when Vidya and Rana break into it to verify his IP address.
Khan is upset when Vidya accidentally kills Sridhar during a scuffle,
Sridhar's computer data reveals a code,
Vidya calls Bhaskaran to tell him that she has retrieved sensitive documents from Sridhar's office.
Vidya asks Bhaskaran to help find her husband in exchange for the documents,
But Bhaskaran tells her to contact the local police.
Vidya soon gets a call from an unknown number, warning her that she should hand over the documents to the caller if she wishes to see her husband alive.
Khan thinks the caller is Damji.

Vidya goes to meet Damji. Damji cuts the meeting short when Vidya expresses her doubt that he will be able to return her husband in exchange for the sensitive file. In the ensuing struggle, Vidya disarms Damji using her prosthetic belly and stabs him with her hairstick before finally killing him with his own gun.
Followed by Rana, Vidya flees into the crowd before the police arrive and leaves a thank-you note for Rana and a pen drive containing data from Sridhar's computer.
Neither Vidya nor Arnab Bagchi ever existed according to Rana.
Vidya is the widow of Major Arup Basu, an IB and Army officer who was killed in the poison-gas attack.
Col. Pratap Bajpayee helped Vidya in her mission to avenge the deaths of Major Arup Basu and their unborn child.
Damji was a colleague of Major Arup Basu.

Advaita Kala was charmed by the warmth of the people in Kolkata, which is reflected in the film.

Vidya started to use a prosthetic belly to look as close to authentically pregnant as possible before the shooting of the film began. She met doctors and pregnant women to learn about the typical lifestyle and nuances of a pregnant woman, and also made lists of rules and superstitions followed by pregnant women.
Ghosh went against the expectations of casting a popular actor from Bollywood and signed Bengali actor Abir Chatterjee to play Vidya's husband instead.
According to Ghosh, popular Bollywood actors were not willing to work with him after his two previous flops.
Several other Bengali film and television actors, such as Indraneil Sengupta and Kharaj Mukherjee, were cast in supporting roles.
Several other Bengali film and television actors, such as Indraneil Sengupta and Kharaj Mukherjee, were cast in supporting roles.

Discussions during the briefing led to the inclusion of paunch in the character Bob Biswas.
Discussions during the briefing led to the inclusion of a bald patch in the character Bob Biswas.

Actor Saswata Chatterjee devised the mannerism of rubbing his nails together as some Indians believe doing that helps prevent hair loss for his character Bob Biswas, which was well-noted and praised by the viewers.
Director Sujoy Ghosh was surprised at how Bob Biswas, portrayed by Saswata Chatterjee, was greeted by fans as a cult figure.

Director Sujoy Ghosh emphasised that the deliberate ordinariness of Bob Biswas was portrayed so convincingly by Saswata Chatterjee that the viewers can expect Bob to be around them at any time and any place.

Filming took place on the streets of Kolkata, where Ghosh often employed the art of guerrilla filmmaking (shooting in real locations without any previous knowledge given to onlookers) to avoid unwanted attention.
The filming locations in Kolkata included Kalighat Metro station, Nonapukur tram depot, Kumartuli, Howrah Bridge, Victoria Memorial, old houses of North Kolkata and others.

The climax, which takes place on the night of Vijayadashami (the last day of Durga Puja), was shot on the night of Vijayadashami in the premises of a Barowari (publicly organised) Durga Puja celebration in the Ballygunge neighbourhood of Kolkata.

The climax, which takes place on the night of Vijayadashami (the last day of Durga Puja), was shot on the night of Vijayadashami in the premises of a Barowari (publicly organised) Durga Puja celebration in the Ballygunge neighbourhood of Kolkata.

Most of the crowd in the climax were not actors. Some actors mingled with the crowd engaged in Sindoor khela[b]—their job was to appreciate the camera angles and accordingly apply sindoor (vermilion) on Vidya's face so that accidental exposure of her eyes to sindoor could be avoided.

Ghosh often employed the art of guerrilla filmmaking (shooting in real locations without any previous knowledge given to onlookers) to avoid unwanted attention.
The cinematographer Setu, who had assisted others in the past to shoot documentaries in Kolkata, said that unlike majority of Indian films, Kahaani was shot mostly without artificial light.
Filming took place on the streets of Kolkata for the film Kahaani.
Unlike majority of Indian films, Kahaani was shot mostly without artificial light.

Kahaani is a woman's film that explores themes of role reversals, breaking stereotypes, turning clichés inside out, and showcases the journey of a strong female character in a male-dominated society. It also delves into feminist themes and examines the concept of motherhood as an instinct to protect one's child.
Vidya Balan portrays a powerful and unconventional female character in Kahaani, breaking the stereotype of a damsel in distress often associated with woman-centric films.
The director's project 'is a study of motherhood', drawing inspiration from the instinct of a mother to protect her baby, which is depicted in Kahaani.
Anurag Ghosh directed and conceptualized Kahaani, showcasing his unique approach to portraying strong female roles and exploring themes of motherhood.

The fleeting hint of romance between Rana and Vidya is a delicate one, which Ghosh considers the most progressive thing in the film. The director explains that the boy, who is initially fascinated by Vidya's computer skills, moves gradually into a zone where he tries to protect her as she is pregnant and a hero in his eyes.

pay a fond yet understated tribute to by incorporating imagery such as yellow taxis, leisurely trams, congested traffic, claustrophobic metros, dilapidated brick houses, tapering alleys, rajnigandhas, lal paad saris, and piping hot luchis. The reviewer notes that Kahaani did not depend on the tropes of Kolkata culture typically used in Bollywood film - O-emphasizing accent, dramatic play of conch shells, rasgulla/mishti doi excesses.
The director acknowledges that Kolkata becomes a central character of the film.
Uddalak Mukherjee of The Telegraph explains that Kolkata in Kahaani was cosmetic and lacked a deep menacing presence.
Gautaman Bhaskaran, writing for Gulf Times, notes that Kolkata imagery was polished up in the film.

node_2: chaos, anxiety and a moral crisis
edge: Uddalak Mukherjee of The Telegraph explains that Kolkata in Kahaani was cosmetic and lacked a deep menacing presence. He argues the depiction of the city never matches the level of Satyajit Ray's Calcutta trilogy, where 'aided by bloodshed, greed and decadence, Calcutta..., even though a place of dreams, desires and hope, slides irreversibly into chaos, anxiety and a moral crisis, taking its residents with it.'
The festival Durga Puja is dedicated to worshiping goddess Durga.
The allegorical yearly return of goddess Durga to slay the demon Mahishasura is alluded to at the end of the film.
The festivities associated with Durga Puja include idols, immersion processions, and pandals.

node_1: women draped in white saris with red borders
edge: The review mentions an entire crowd of women draped in white saris with red borders as being central to the film's visual aesthetic during Durga Puja.
The review praises the depiction of Durga Puja festivities in Kolkata, a city well known for its celebration of Durga Puja.

Ghosh was inspired by particular scenes of Ray's Aranyer Dinratri to shoot a similar scene, hoping the audience would become 'like Vidya’s fellow passenger.'

node_2: films of the 1970s and 1980s, such as deewaar (1975)
edge: Ghosh admits inspiration from 'visually striking' films of the 1970s and 1980s, including Deewaar (1975), for his film Kahaani.
Critics have compared the fake-pregnancy twist of Kahaani with the 2004 American psychological thriller Taking Lives.
Sequences towards the end that explain the missing pieces of the mystery in Kahaani were compared with The Usual Suspects (1995).
Ghosh writes that the film was heavily influenced by the colour scheme of the Pratima Visarjan, a c.1915 watercolour by the Bengal School artist Gaganendranath Tagore.
The film score of Kahaani is composed by Clinton Cerejo.
The soundtrack album of Kahaani is composed by Vishal–Shekhar.

The film Kahaani was released on the day after International Women's Day.
The film Kahaani played on 1100 screens worldwide.
Distributors deferred the release of Kahaani, fearing that Vidya's role might not be received well after her role in The Dirty Picture.
According to CNN-IBN, Kahaani was ready before The Dirty Picture, but distributors deferred its release due to Vidya's role in the latter.
The Indian television premiere of Kahaani was on Star India's channel Movies OK.
Distributed by Shemaroo Entertainment, the DVD of Kahaani was released across all regions in a one-disc pack.
The film Kahaani received critical acclaim.
According to review aggregator Review Gang, the film received a rating of 7.5 out of 10.
Taran Adarsh of Bollywood Hungama gave the film 4 out of 5 stars and praised Vidya's acting.

node_2: displaying more 'male ornaments' than most heroes

In March 2012, Sujoy Ghosh announced his intention to develop Kahaani into a series, inspired by Satyajit Ray's Feluda detective series and wanting to continue the stories of Vidya Bagchi on similar lines.
Kahaani's protagonist, portrayed by Vidya Balan, is named Vidya Bagchi.

In February 2014, Vidya announced that the sequel was not happening due to differences between Sujoy Ghosh and other co-producers. However, two years later, Ghosh confirmed that the film, entitled Kahaani 2, was in pre-production with Vidya set to reprise her role.
In the sequel of Kahaani, entitled Kahaani 2, Vidya Balan reprised her role.
In Kahaani 2, Arjun Rampal played the lead role opposite Vidya Balan.
Bob Biswas is a spin-off to Kahaani, featuring Abhishek Bachchan as Bob Biswas and Chitrangada Singh as his wife.
Bob Biswas is the directorial debut of Diya Annapurna Ghosh, daughter of Sujoy Ghosh who directed Kahaani.
